nodes.text: A land price bubble can arise even when observed housing rent-to-price ratio is constant (non-vanishing) provided one distinguishes pure land rent from housing-structure rent
A simple overlapping generations model demonstrates existence of equilibria with a land bubble while aggregate housing rent-to-price ratio equals a constant

Method: Two-period overlapping generations economy with consumption good and housing service, Cobb-Douglas utility with parameters beta_y, beta_o, beta_h summing to one, unit land supply durable and non-reproducible

Method: Representative firm produces perishable housing structure using construction material M and land X via homogeneous degree-1, concave production function F satisfying standard monotonicity and an Inada-type condition

Result: Consumer optimization and market clearing imply land price Pt equals beta_o times endowment e_t (Pt = beta_o e_t) and optimal expenditures (beta_y e_t, beta_o e_t, beta_h e_t) on young consumption, old consumption discounted, and housing rent
Proposition 1 (Claim/Result): Aggregate rent-to-price ratio r_t h_t / P_t is constant and equals beta_h / beta_o
Equilibrium condition: Mt (construction input) is uniquely determined by equation F/FM (Mt,1) = beta_h e_t, yielding dividends Dt = (FX/FM)(Mt,1)
Bubble characterization (Evidence): By Bubble Characterization Lemma, a land bubble exists iff the infinite sum over t of dividend yield Dt/Pt is finite
Proposition 2 (Result): In the model, there is a land bubble iff sum over t of FX/F (Mt,1) is finite, where Mt solves the equilibrium condition

Proposition 3 (Result): For CES production F with elasticity sigma > 1, FX/F asymptotics imply a land bubble iff sum over t of e_t^{1/sigma - 1} is finite; with persistent economy growth e_t ~ G^t (G>1) this condition holds, so land bubbles inevitably emerge

Context: Previous skepticism argued rational land or housing bubbles are implausible because dividend or rent-to-price ratios are observed to be stationary while bubble theory predicts vanishing dividend yields

Method detail: Young agents buy land and housing rent, old agents consume from sale proceeds and land dividend; combined budget yields tractable Cobb-Douglas expenditure shares used to solve equilibrium
Assumption: Production function F is CES example with parameters A, alpha, sigma; empirical estimates suggest sigma > 1 is plausible for housing production
Method: Equilibrium defined by utility maximization, profit maximization, and market clearing for consumption, housing, and land; yields unique equilibrium characterized analytically

Conclusion: Empirical dismissal of land bubbles based solely on stationary observed housing price-to-rent ratios is flawed; one must separate pure land rent from housing-structure rent to evaluate land bubbles
